column3: A class in C++ is a blueprint for creating objects.
In C++ private members of a class can be accessed directly by objects.
Which keyword in C++ is used to define a class?
column6: a) struct b) class c) object d) typedef

column3: What does the concept of encapsulation in OOP mean?
column6: a) Wrapping data and methods into a single unit b) Reusing code through inheritance c) Deriving new classes from existing ones d) Creating multiple functions with the same name

column3: In C++ the special member function that initializes an object is called the __.
A destructor in C++ has the same name as the class prefixed with a tilde (~).
Polymorphism allows functions to have the same name but different implementations.
Which type of inheritance allows a class to inherit from multiple base classes?
column6: a) Single b) Multilevel c) Hierarchical d) Multiple

column3: Which access specifier in C++ allows members to be accessible within the class and its derived classes?
column6: a) private b) protected c) public d) static

column3: The __ keyword in C++ is used to allocate memory dynamically.
Abstract classes cannot be instantiated in C++.
Virtual functions in C++ allow achieving runtime polymorphism.
What is the purpose of the 'this' pointer in C++?
column6: a) Refers to the current object b) Stores the base class address c) Points to the derived class d) Allocates memory for the object

column3: Which of the following is an example of compile-time polymorphism in C++?
column6: a) Virtual functions b) Function overloading c) Dynamic type casting d) Operator new

column3: The process of defining multiple functions with the same name but different parameters is called __.
